reviewText:
The Culling of the Cows stands between Plants Versus Zombies (Or old farmer vs zombie cows -- and possibly nazi aliens) and a sidescrolling shooter.
This is made by Decaying Logic, the same developers that brought us Radical Roach, which I reviewed a while ago (and was not impressed at all).

While I believe this is definitely an improvement over Radical Roach, many of the same flaws and design choices are present in this game, just to a lesser extent.


As usual, I'll start with presentation.
Not unlike their previous game, the Artstyle is probably one of the defining points. While it feels like flash, the animations are pretty good, although a bit too limited (there is only one animation for each enemy, it seems, as well as the carcass sprite, which makes the field end up looking a bit too monotonous).
The interface templates don't really seem to fit the theme, but it's not too bad. Other visuals effects are also subpar, against the cartoony style they were mostly going for.
There are a few different areas that slightly change the look of the map, but don't be fooled, as the map doesn't change at all, except for the visuals.
One problem I've had with it, is that the dead bodies cover up the screen by the end of the levels, to the point that you can't see new enemies arrive very clearly. That should definitely be changed. Other than that, it's fine.

The Music is also very similar to Radical Roach. It's not awful, and it has some good moments, but it's very repetitive, and doesn't loop very well, which is unfortunate. It's upbeat, and a mixture between some rock/metal and electronic music which goes for the more arcade vibe than atmosphere. There are some old sci-fi melodies though, which is a nice addition.
One improvement that I want to stress is that the music no longer restarts whenever you fail a level! It's a weird aspect to consider, but I think it's very important. It didn't happen in RR, and it was really annoying to listen the song start over and over again. Now, it doesn't happen, and it's a subtle but important improvement, in my opinion!



So, let's talk about the Mechanics.
As I said, it's has a bit of PvZ in it. Essentially, you have a large lane to defend agains the zombies. There are no specific lanes as in PvZ, you can freely walk around, and so can the enemies. You have a shotgun, different ammo types, upgrades, and assists. You'll also, periodically, be able to call for a crate with a random power-up.
Your job is to stop zombies from entering the barn, and also avoid being killed by them (if they hit you). Pretty straightforward.

You have a world map with the levels spread around (unlocking more as you go) with a couple of spreading paths, somewhat like One Finger Death Punch, only much smaller. These levels include a few different modes. reviewText:
If anything this game is going to be a hit and miss affair with you, as it did with me. The game is essentially a defence title, with an assortment of monsters rushing into the barn, and as the farmer it is your job to prevent the said monstrosities from getting in. If you fail a certain number of times, the stage is over and you have to restart again.

To mix up the formula some monsters act a little different to one another, along with varying amounts of hit points. To aid the chaotic game play, players can also summon a few tactical skills on the field, along with some limited and temporary upgrades to the shotgun.

Repeat the same formula with increasing difficulties for dozens of stages and you get the general idea of how this goes. Every rarely you’ll get to fight a boss or two, but they’re way too simple to pose a challenge.

The art style is hand drawn and mostly consistent, like the game play that may not strike everyone’s fancy either, but it sat well enough for me. The biggest problem I had with the game was that it lacked a sense of progression, you’ll upgrade your weapon level after level, but they never stick. There is also little point to divert from the main path and complete every stage, since there is nothing to unlock or to accomplish.

For the low price though, I would recommend it for a decent distraction.

The Culling of The Cows is a lane defense zombie shoot-em-up festival.  You play as a farmer defending his barn from ever increasing waves of zombies and zombie cows. There is a large variety of what enemies you face as well as various weapons and defense assists that keep the gameplay feeling fresh.

One positive addition to the game is the special achievements, which adds to the ways you can enjoy the game.  The interface is simplistic, as is the gameplay. That being said, it is high paced with a feeling of momentum, and a great threat level. If you find it too easy, there are achievements that add a new layer. It can be repetitive, and I would have liked to see a lot more maps.  The weight of your weapon has impact, and it's satisfying to see your enemies explode.

This game is enjoyable, but has a feeling of 'the same'.  It is a casual game, but it does what it needs to do very well.  I never felt like my time was wasted, or that I wasn't being respected by the game.  If this game looks enjoyable to you, I can easily recommend it.

Quick Summary – An (almost) casual wave shooter game with simplified mechanics. This is just like one of those browser games that you can find on Newgrounds or Kongregate that you can play for an hour or two at a time. Give it a try if you like that sort of thing, it’s a small download size.

You play an old dude with a shotgun defending your farm against (zombie?) cows charging at you on a small 3D field.  You can move up down and side to side but the screen doesn’t scroll. The zombie cows of various speeds and toughness will run from right to left toward you and you need to blast them before they get into the barn you’re guarding on the left side of the screen. To help you on your task, you can purchase gun upgrades and different types of ammo (buckshot, exploding, etc.) in each level, or use “assists” such as sentry guns or firewalls that are free but on cooldown timers.

Pros:
+Simple gameplay that can occupy you maybe 30 minutes at a time when you have nothing better to do. Each level is maybe 5-10 minutes long and not too hard once you get the hang of it.
+There are some humor elements to the game so even though each level is mostly the same, you can get a couple laughs.

Cons:
-There are maybe 50 levels of the same gameplay and you may get bored pretty quick.

Overall the game is fun for a short time and if you’re like me, you’ll probably be done with it after getting the easy Steam achievements. Play it and forget it.

reviewText:
The Culling Of The Cows is a short game, in which you play as a farmer during a zombie apocalypse, only that, instead of human zombies (well, there are some of them), there are cow zombies. Armed only with a shotgun, you must defend your barn from these zombies.

Even though you have a single weapon through most of the game (the aforementioned shotgun), there's two extra weapons that appear in specific levels: a machine gun, and a rocket launcher. Even then, the shotgun can use four different types of ammo, and there's several upgrades for it, that make it even better at killing stuff. You can also get supply drops (like extra cash for upgrading your weapon, invincibility, etc), and use different abilities to kill the zombies, like providing your barn with a machine gun, or a saw, sending a nuke, etc.

Even though the idea of shooting cows might sound dull at first, there's a good variety of enemies: different types of cows (even cows strapped with TNT, helpful for blowing up nearby cows!), and, as already mentioned, a few human enemies. There's also crows falling from the sky.

As far as gameplay goes, all the levels consist of you defending your barn against waves of enemies (or against a single, large wave), with a few changes: in most of the levels, you're in front of your barn, and the cows can kill you, while in a few Onslaught" levels
date: you shoot the cows from the safety of your barn's second floor.\n\nNice game
recommended: once you get the hang of it. I recommend it."

Homemade spghetti sauce
Serves: 8-10
Prep time:  15 mins Cook time:  3 hours Total time:  3 hours 15 mins
Ingredients:
3-4 cans of Crushed Tomatoes (either regular or with basil, oregano and garlic) 28 oz. sized cans OR 12-15 fresh tomatoes (peeled, chopped and blended in a food processor)
4 cloves of garlic
A bunch of dried basil (probably 3-5 Tbsp)
A bunch of black pepper ( probably 1 - 2 tsp)
1 TBSP of Sugar (optional)
2 TSBP olive oil
⅓ cup of grated Parmesan or Romano Cheese
Minced Green Peppers (optional)
Instrucktions:
1.Heat the olive oil in a 5+ qt. pot over medium heat, and add the chopped or pressed garlic.
Heat for one to two minutes, making sure not to burn the garlic, then add all the tomatoes, black pepper, basil and sugar. Stirring often, bring to a low boil.
Reduce heat to low and simmer for 2-3 hours stirring often.
For the first half of the simmer time, do so with the pot uncovered, then cover.
Add the cheese, stir in and simmer for an additional 5 minutes or so.
This will make the equivalent to 4-5 jars of sauce, and the cost is probably about half (and it tastes way better).

The game is better than Radical Roach (by the same dev). That's not saying much though. DO NOT. I repeat DO NOT buy this at any price above 50 cent. You'll find free flash games better than this. The reason you would pay anything above zero is because at the very least it drop trading cards and there is a mild amusement factor thrown in.

Pros:
-Theme. Okay, I like the zombie cows and old farmer as the protagonist.

Cons:
-Hit box. About the worst thing in the game. It is so inconsistent. You can be hitting cows in the head at one moment and in the next watch bullets zip through like ghosts. This is especially evident when old farmer shooting from the barn window as zombie cows dance around. There's been many times when I get hit by a cow just right after a shot just whiz past. Oh yeah, of course it's a one hit kill.
-Reload speed. You are given a reload button but cannot reload as fast as your thumb pressing on the dang thing. If that's by design it's a really poor choice for a shooter that depends on it. As level progress cows come up faster & faster and in greater numbers. When you have to manage between shooting, reload, inventory purchase, and support from above and you come up blank do to reload response isn't there, it's really frustrating. (FYI, I'm using a 360 controller)
-Spawning at the start of level. This is old school cheap method of making a game longer than it really is.
-Repetition. I have to mention this even though it is expected of this type of game. It's the very least of concern (see above).

Shooters require tight controls and mechanics which this game does not have, making it not only challenging but frustrating. I simply cannot recommend it. Only get this is it's a bundle filler or given free.

reviewText:
For a silly shooter defense type game where you defend your farm from cows and what not... I'd say this is a game worth playing.

Many things were enjoyable such as the following:

Positives:
♦ Almost Each level is unique
♦ Every level you beat unlocks new enemies
♦ Every level you beat unlocks new support items
♦ Unique way to upgrade weapons
♦ Breaks between waves
♦ Random Events in the form of a deployable Crate
♦ Hilarious story and voice overs
♦ Achievements for playing the game basically

Now don't get me wrong there are many positives, but still not every game is perfect and this one has the following negative points:

Negatives:
♦ Accuracy of the shots are slightly off
♦ Cheats which can be used to get the achievements
♦ Waves per level are way too long
♦ Can get repetitive quite quickly
♦ Little overpriced as I got mine in a bundle and Indiegala gave it away free

Improvements:
♦ Fix the Accuracy
♦ Make Cheats only usable once finished the game
♦ Lower Waves per round (So it feels less repetitive)

Overall, in my opinion, the game is hillarious, fun and worth playing despite the accuracy of shots being slightly off and the slight repetitiveness. Though if you don't use cheats, enjoy easy to get achievements and love a laugh whilst playing a video game, then I highly recommend this for you.

Overall, I'd rate this 3.5/5!

PS: If you try and get all the stars for every level in the game, you'll be there for a while making this game have very godo replay value!

The Last Stand is a free Flash game, and it's much better than this, because it avoided Cows' glaring design flaws.

The biggest problem is that you can't aim your shotgun freely - it's always pointed straight across the screen, like in an old arcade game. Even though you are clearly firing a spread of pellets from your shotgun, you have to be very careful that you're not too high or too low to hit the stampeding cow (all of which KILL YOU IN ONE HIT). Again, I'm used to this kind of system from old arcade games, but it feels unfair in this game, especially given the way that cows will run in fast at a diagonal. There's actually a laser sight upgrade for your shotgun, but it doesn't help much.

Your shotgun has a high ammo capacity (especially if you upgrade it) but you have to reload each shell manually by pressing R. (This is more annoying than it sounds).

You have sentry guns and such that you can activate to kill some cows for you, but you have to activate most of them at just the right time, which is not really practical with the standard mouse+keyboard controls.

...What's that you say? You'll just use a controller with a nice, convenient button for each trap? Nope, sorry, but controller support is AWFUL. You can only move around with the directional pad (the sticks do nothing!), and there are no dedicated buttons for the traps and upgrades. (The game actually tells you Controllers are for ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥!" when you select it in the options menu. That's the quite the excuse for terrible support...)

TL;DR: Simple fast-paced, albeit short, wave defender. I'd advice to get it on discount.

In Culling of the Cows you slaughter hundreds of cows, a couple of badgers and also some hipsters. All of them are zombies though. There's a reason for that revealed at the end but it's totally ridiculous like the whole idea itself. For whatever reason you don't want the monsters in your barn. You got to go through the farm utterly destroying all the undead bovine life forms with your trusty shotgun and (!) the muda♥♥♥♥ing airforces.

Perhaps surprisingly, this is rather fun and enjoyable. Voice acting is horrible though but for that matter the game lasts only couple of hours even if you try to ace everything.

Every level you begin with a shotgun shooting slugs. God promises to sell you better weapons and help along the way because he's a such good guy. He also sends you money to pay for all the stuff. Then you proceed to kill all the enemies rampaging towards you. You got to reload manually so proceed with care and precision. This can be annoying as the hitboxes are quite small. This also makes the spread-out ammo upgrade super useful.

Frankly, you can only shoot forward and you're slow at walking, so sometimes you can't prevent a cow from passing or indeed killing you. This is where assists come in: you can call up airforces, bombings, sentry guns, fire walls, all kinds of overpowered defenses that will mostly take care of your job for you, with brief cooldowns in between. Still it often takes another try to ace any level, especially since that means you can't buy some overpowered weapons.

It wouldn't stay fresh for long but fortunately it's also quite short, the 40 levels taking only some 2-3 hours to ace. However, the short length is also a curse: it's not really worth the full price. However, at a decent discount or in a bundle, go for it.

This is a typical wave based 2D shoot em up. It has a funny little gimmic which is basically a nazi ufo turns the cows into zombies. So it's not that serious.

Graphics:  The art style is okay, nothing special. Looks like a flash game.

Sound:  The enemies have good sounds (except that annoying crow) just like the weapons. I think the voice over work is rly cheesy sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't. The music is repetitive as hell you won't stand it longer than like 2,3 levels. The problem is basically there is a 30 sec loop and nothing else except for the menu music.

Gameplay:  You have to shoot down cows and other enemies in front of you. There are many types of enemies like super fast cow,
tank cow, a crazy cow that comes at you in a crisscross and many more. So the enemy variety is good. But the algorithm is easy: Is this guy ahead of the others? -> shoot OR is this guy faster than the others? -> shoot that first.
There are game modes like simple turret sectons, boss fights, 1 big wave, normal wave. You can upgrade your shotgun in the previous 2. There are ammo types like birdshot, buckshot, slug... each is different but I think the buckshot is your bread and butter because it shoots in a cone. And the awkward hit detection (or the sense of position I'm not sure) is really annoying and it puts you out of the mood. You can also upgrade your ammo capacity, reload speed, fire rate, and you can attach a laser pointer on your shotgun. These upgrades can be obtained by your starter and drop money. You can also call for a care packege which contains money or powerups like unlimited ammo, unlimited health, slomo... for a limited time. But I walked through them almost every time because of the awkward sense of position.
You can also call aids like air strike, napalm barrels, nuke and other over the top stuff.
The game gets really repetitive after 30-60 minutes. There is only one level type (The Farm) but it indicates like there will be other themes but no... just the farm.

Replayability:  There are achievements per stage but you mustn't use the upgrade system or the aid system to earn these which defeats the only good thing in the game.

Overall:   Pros:
Setting
Nice upgrade system and air support bonuses
Gore
Trading Cards
Casual fun time for a few hours  Cons:
Only 1 weapon (except for the turret segments)
Annoying hit detection and sense of position
Music is bad and repetitive
Lack of variety in levels
Questionable game design
The Extras menu leads you to nowhere...
HIgh price!
Verdict:  It's not worth 11 euros for sure. If you want some mindless fun for a few hours then buy it on a sale. I had some fun but I had many many frustrated moments as well. It's an average game at best. Won't kill you but won't save you.
My recomendation is neutral but the actual price lowers it a little bit. Oh and if you want to play it the fun" way it lasts 2 hours."

The Culling of the Cows is... well bland.

I’m not sure exactly what the genre would be called; you are an old farmer with a shot gun taking out mutant/zombie cows before they can reach the barn behind you. It’s the kind of goofy flash game you would see on Newgrounds back in the day, but not one you would ever be expected to pay for. The movement is a little stiff and the shots don’t actually seem to register correctly about 1/3 of the time, which is exacerbated by the flat south park-esque characters giving you no good indication of depth down range. I played it for around 20 or 30 minutes and was quite bored, then booted it back up when I noticed an announcement on the Library page: Cheat Codes Added. Generally cheat codes end up ruining the fun of a game, but in a game like this maybe skipping to the excitement would keep me engaged for at least a while longer. I activated God Mode, unlocked all the upgrades, and added an MG nest to the top of the barn; awesome right? Except it wasn’t. There wasn’t any big spectacle, the MG was anemic at best, and God Mode only lasted roughly 15 seconds.

I don’t know if I’m missing something or if there are some shady things going on because the overall consensus is Very Positive at the time of writing this. I got this as a free key from some bundle website a while back and I almost regret having it in my library. It functions enough to be acceptable on a flash game website but I’ll be hiding it in my Steam library and never touching it again.

Although I do love this game and enjoy it, I am not recommending it due to some issues that make it not worth the price of $13. Here are the issues:

Repetitiveness:
Obviously in any tower-defense type of game you are going to see some repetitiveness involving the levels that you play. However, I feel that this game does an okay job when it comes to level variety. There are 3 types of levels that you can play,  but they are all basically the same type of level just with a minor change that doesn't make it stand out to the others.

Lag:
Although I do not usually write about lagging issues in a review due to me playing on a laptop and it usually being on my side of the experience, there is a major issue that needs to fixed ASAP. This has to do with the dead bodies left on the screen. If you notice in any other tower-defense game such as Plants Vs. Zombies for example, the bodies always disappear after a short while of sitting on the ground. This game does not do that, and I found that as I progress on through the waves of enemies, their bodies stay laying on the ground and actually cause the game to slow down and lag making it nearly impossible to successfully complete the level.

So is the game fun? Yes. I enjoy this game very much cause it does a great job at being a game that is challenging while still being fun. Is it worth $13? As it stands, no. The only reason I got this game was through a key giveaway for the game and I of course enjoy free games. I was shocked however to see that the price of this game to be $13 when stopping by to write a review. The game needs a lot of work before it would be worth that price, but if you don't mind it go ahead and buy it however I will not recommend this game for these reasons.

There is something infinitely rewarding about slaughtering so many zombie cows that you can't see the ground texture anymore. COTC is simple and harkens to the classic flash game setup, but one thing that most can't deny is that it's downright polished, and lovingly polished at that.

You have a shotgun. God supports you with farming equiptment and artillery strikes. There is a nazi UFO flying around. There are cows. Zombie cows. There are also some normal zombies sometimes. No one cares about those. You shoot them til they're all dead, as of God's urging.

This is all you need to know, and honestly, it's not for everyone. The insanely cheap pricetag demands some respect, and there is a surprising amount of content to be had, with a wide variety of levels and challenges, on top of some badge challenges that, while have no incentive, are a fun thing to try and aim for. There are multiple shell types, and each are fun to mess around with, but the buck shot is usually your best bet. You get the point.

The artstyle is absolutely lovely, and the voicework, while obnoxious after a point, is surprisingly competant and hammy.
There is an ending, and an overall plot, which has a kind of sweet if you can get past the final boss (it's a doozy, trust me), but for basic stupid arcade slaughter, you'll absolutely get your money's worth.

Not for everyone, and arguably not worth the full price.

Definitely looking forward to whatever the developers do that isn't a bunch of jigsaw puzzles.
